name: Geography BA
overview: The Geography major allows students to combine a broad background in the field with more specific interests and career goals. Students can select classes in several areas of geography such as urban, economic, cultural, environmental, physical, or biogeography. They should consult with the undergraduate adviser to plan a program suitable to their personal objectives.

sections.title: Entry to the Major
sections.description: Requirements to declare the major for current students and for transfer applicants.

requirements.title: Admission
requirements.description: To declare the major, students must have completed two geography courses with a grade-point average of 2.0 or better.

requirements.title: Transfer Students
requirements.description: Transfer applicants to the Geography major with 90 or more units must complete as many of the following introductory courses as possible prior to admission to UCLA. Refer to the UCLA transfer admission guide for up-to-date information regarding transfer selection for admission.

sections.title: The Major
sections.description: Complete 11 upper-division geography courses (44 units minimum).

requirements.title: Upper-Division Geography Courses
requirements.description: Complete 11 courses. All geography upper-division courses numbered 100 and higher may be applied toward the major, with a few exceptions. Contact the advising office for more information.

sections.title: Honors Program
sections.description: The departmental honors program is designed for Geography majors who are interested in completing a research project that culminates in an honors thesis. To qualify for graduation with departmental honors, students must have a cumulative grade-point average (GPA) of 3.5 or better in all upper-division geography courses and a 3.0 overall GPA.

requirements.title: Honors Thesis Track
requirements.description: Choose to complete the Honors Thesis Track (optional).

options.title: Required Honors Courses
options.description: Students must enroll in Geography 198A and 198B in two consecutive terms and earn grades of A– or better.
